Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the clinic wall, my stomach already rumbling as lunchtime approached. My last patient before the break, Mrs. Feldman, sat across from me, sniffling and coughing. Her symptoms pointed to a common cold, but I knew I had to be thorough—my duty as a doctor demanded it. I asked more questions, ordered a quick test, and reassured her, all the while thinking about the kosher vendor a few blocks away. It was the only place I could eat while traveling, and it would close soon for the afternoon. If I rushed, I might make it. But if I hurried through Mrs. Feldman’s exam, I risked missing something important, betraying my professional standards. Yet, if I stayed too long, I’d have nothing kosher to eat, violating my religious commitment. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my responsibility to my patient and my obligation to my faith—each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time. My pen hovered over Mrs. Feldman’s chart, my mind torn between the two worlds I called my own.
